title: 1095-B
statement: B. Array Stabilizationtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an array $$$a$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ integer numbers.Letinstabilityof the array be the following value: $$$\\max\\limits_{i = 1}^{n} a_i - \\min\\limits_{i = 1}^{n} a_i$$$.You have to removeexactly oneelement from this array to minimizeinstabilityof the resulting $$$(n-1)$$$-elements array. Your task is to calculate the minimum possibleinstability.InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$) — the number of elements in the array $$$a$$$.The second line of the input contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le 10^5$$$) — elements of the array $$$a$$$.OutputPrint one integer — the minimum possibleinstabilityof the array if you have to removeexactly oneelement from the array $$$a$$$.ExamplesInput4 1 3 3 7Output2Input2 1 100000Output0NoteIn the first example you can remove $$$7$$$ theninstabilityof the remaining array will be $$$3 - 1 = 2$$$.In the second example you can remove either $$$1$$$ or $$$100000$$$ theninstabilityof the remaining array will be $$$100000 - 100000 = 0$$$ and $$$1 - 1 = 0$$$ correspondingly.

processed.result: You are given an array of $n$ integers.  The *instability* of the array is the difference between the largest and smallest numbers in the array.  You must remove exactly one number from the array to make the instability as small as possible.  Find the minimum possible instability.
You are given a list of numbers.  Find the smallest difference between the largest and smallest numbers in the list after removing one number.
